bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, May 29, 1923

div1.p: Carter writes that more work is needed to eliminate yellow fever. He discusses the recent yellow fever outbreak in Columbia. Carter also comments on the origins of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, May 29, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
Miscl
Hanson
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
May 29, 1923.
Dear Doctor Hanson:
div1.p:
Your letter received. I am certainly sorry about Carl, but hope
it will turn out all right.

Russell was in Friday and I mentioned the probability of your
leaving Jacksonville--of which he took note. Says he can make no con-
tract for any period in yellow fever work, but that Connor had stayed
since 1918, including more than half of thay year: Vaughn: Bailey et al
since the spring of 1920.

In my judgment--and I am sorry to say it--it looks as if we had
possibly a rather long work ahead in yellow fever--say 2 to 5 years.
If the rubber industry on the Amazon is revived and Hackett tells me
there is, yes, a threat of it, the chance is good to reinfect this
whole valley from Ceara, where there is considerable yellow fever at
present. This state has hitherto furnished practically all of the im-
ported rubber gatherers (Seringãos). I don't know enough yet about the
Colombian focus to form any estimate of it, except if (when) it reaches
the coast it imperils Central America and Mexico.

I have not finished the matter of place origin, but as far as I
have gone the historical evidence is very decidedly against it being
America: the biological--both man and aegypti--is also against America.

I am enclosing a carbon of a piece written for the Australian
Health Authorities through the I. H. B. Note especially what is said
about other species of Stegomyia and African conditions. Note too that
while the epidemiological evidence practically excludes resevoir hosts
in America, we have none I mean no evidence from Africa, where I am inclined to think, yel-
yel-
low fever originated.

With very best remembrances, in which Laura, who is typing this,
joins, and hoping for good news about Carl soon.
div1.closer:
Very truly your friend, H. R. Carter. Dictated, but not read.
2 enclosures.
Please return enclosed carbon, as it is the only one I have.
H. R. C.
